repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Indigenous Management of Protected
            Areas in the Peruvian Amazon (GEF) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Indigenous Management of
            Protected Areas in the Peruvian Amazon (GEF) Project for
            Peru were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk
            to development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance
            was satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the project
            proved that communities' participation is positive for
            biodiversity conservation, which was its original principle.
            Indeed, communities were a driving force during project
            execution through a participation process that encouraged
            co-responsibility and intercultural dialogue. The project
            demonstrated the feasibility of combining conventional
            conservation with an indigenous conception of protected
            areas as their living environment. The project showed that
            co management required enabling indigenous communities by
            building their capacity to directly execute activities
            affecting their livelihoods. Training under the project
            responded to this demand and has been a key element in the
            development of the co management model because: (i) it is an
            instrument that has helped to strengthen and empower people
            to achieve social change; (ii) it was promoted as an
            intercultural dialogue in which both sides learned from each
            other; and (iii) it was custom-made to adapt to local
            capacity and cultural background.

repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Indigenous Management of Protected
            areas in the Peruvian Amazon Project (GEF)

abstracts.cdata!:
The Indigenous Management of Protected
            Areas in the Peruvian Amazon Project aims to increase the
            sustainability of biodiversity conservation by involving
            indigenous communities in the management of new and existing
            protected areas. There are four project components. The
            first 1) prepares planning documents and the consultative
            process for creating one new protected area and the
            permanent categorization of three existing reserved zones;
            2) establishes protected area management committees; 3)
            creates a community-based and -managed protected area
            surveillance system; 4) trains indigenous community leaders
            in participatory methods; 5) implements a public awareness
            program; 6) builds and refurbishes facilities; 7) involves
            local staff and specialists; and 8) finances office,
            transportation, and communications equipment. The second
            component prepares management plans for titled indigenous
            land; technical studies and demand and market studies; and
            provides biodiversity investment sub-grants. The third
            component establishes a monitoring and evaluation unit at
            the central level and zonal levels and contracts for an
            analysis of the conservation and socioeconomic status of
            project areas and baseline information; develops biological
            and socio-economic databases and a geographical information
            system; prepares monitoring plans; and trains staff and
            local indigenous promoters.
